structural_unit_name.en: Johan Skytte Institute of Political Studies

description.en: This course introduces Estonian culture, language, geography, history and politics to first year international masters students at the Skytte institute. Relying on a variety of examples from different cultural domains, the course gives an overview of the hopes and fears, joys and disappointments of Estonian life.
description.et: Kursus käsitleb sissejuhatavas võtmes Eesti kultuuri, keelt, geograafiat, ajalugu ja poliitikat Skytte instituuti õppima asunud rahvusvahelistele magistrantidele. Tuginedes arvukatele näidetele erinevatest kultuurivaldkondadest, annab kursus ülevaate Eesti elu lootustest ja hirmudest, rõõmudest ja pettumustest.

objectives.en: The course aims to help international masters students get oriented to Estonian culture, language, geography, history, politics, and current events.
objectives.et: Kursuse eesmärgiks on tutvustada rahvusvahelistele magistrantidele erinevaid Eesti kultuuri tahke (kultuurilugu, keel, geograafia, ajalugu ja poliitika).

learning_outcomes.en:
Upon finishing the course students should be able:  
To speak intelligently and with some degree of subtlety about Estonia's cultural, historical, geographical, linguistic, and political place in the world and its internal diversity and divisions.   
To be a good cultural ambassador to Estonia upon return to their home country or elsewhere in the world.

independent_work.et:
Readings and preparations for class discussions. 

Interview assignment 

Weekly postings 

 

The guidelines to all assignments will be posted in Moodle and discussed in the first meeting. 

 

Consultations with the instructor available upon request.

description.et:
INTERVIEW:  Conduct an interview with a local Estonian about the story of their grandparents answering questions about their place of birth, family life, ethnic identity, work, and memories and impressions of the Soviet past and Singing Revolution, etc. 
Pass/ Fail (25% for completion)

WEEKLY POSTINGS: each week students should post something small to cultural forum to share and discuss with the class that is related to the theme of that week - e.g. an Estonian political joke, a favorite passage from an assigned text or film clip, photograph of a Estonian monument with a few words about its meaning, a  recommendation on a museum exhibition or place to visit, etc. 
Pass/ Fail (25% for completion)

ORAL PARTICIPATION:  if enrollments are small, then class participation will entail discussion of the show and tell postings collectively.  If enrollments are large than these conversations will happen in smaller groups, each of which will appoint a representative to speak to the entire class. 
Pass/ Fail (50% for completion)

grade_preconditions.et: Pass-Fail Course:  to pass attendance is required in at  least 50% of class sessions, completion of the interview assignment, and at least half of the weekly postings.

grade_evaluation.et:
50% active oral particpation 

25% weekly show and tell postings 

25% interview assignment

name.en: Johan Skytte Institute of Political Studies

structural_unit.address:
Lossi 36, ruum 301
51003 Tartu linn, 
Tartu linn, Tartumaa 
EST

description.et: WELCOME TO ESTONIA!  Estonia's geopolitical place on the world stage and internal geography and demography in 14 linguistic cases.
A SILENT OR A SINGING NATION?  The stereotype of Estonian silence, Estonian music from Arvo Pärt to Metsatöll, the song festival tradition and the Singing Revolution.

CAN-DO POLITICS AND CAN'T-DO HUMOR:   The "can-do" optimism of Estonian political culture ("teeme ära" and "ükskord me võidame niikuinii") and the "can't-do" pessimism of Estonian humor ("tujurikkuja" and the land of "no sex and no future"); Estonian individualism and what it means to be "tubli"

BETWEEN THE FOREST AND THE SEA:  Nature's place in Estonian culture, from its mythological Finno-Ugric roots (Kalevipoeg, Kivirähk, Mikita, etc) to Estonian environmentalism, ÖÖD houses and what it means to have a "suvila"

TRUTH AND JUSTICE:  Peasant values in an increasingly urban world; social justice in Estonian life and literature from Tammsaare's "Tõde ja õigus" to today and the meaning of  the best-known phrase in Estonian Literature:  "Tee tööd ja näe vaeva, siis tuleb ka armastus."
THE UNSPEAKABLE PAST: "Risttuules" (In the Crosswind), the Bronze Soldier, national trauma, collaboration, the politics of memory.
FAMILIAR STRANGERS:  Cultural "selves" (omad) and "others" (võõrad) in the Estonian "semiosphere": Russians, Germans, Finns, Latvians, and Foreign Estonians, some more familiar than others.
E-ESTONIA OR EKRE?  Globalism and nationalism in Estonian politics and everyday life from the ongoing search for an Estonian "Nokia" to the uniquely Estonian meanings of "õnn" and "edu"
